displayed_text: Patient: Tired. Doctor: Tired? How about the diarrhea stuff? Did it happen again? Patient: Um, hmm. Doctor: After the last chemo? Okay. Let me take a look at your belly. Patient: mumbling (sound of door) Doctor: Here I’ll take that. Remember to take it okay with you. Oh! Careful. Don’t lean on that chair. Patient: Ow! Doctor: That’s the same (speaking softly) Patient: No. Patient: Awww. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Okay so and you had quite a bit of this current chemotherapy that you’ve been on. Okay so we’ve given you about twelve cycles, but the good thing is it has worked and has kept the cancer in check all this time. The other good thing is that I didn’t see any other new areas. So the lung, liver, none of those were involved. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Every six months. Doctor: Right. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Right. Patient: I thought it was, I thought it was longer than that, but okay. Doctor: And then once we get a few years out beyond that, once we get out to five years, then we’ll start making it every year. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: But after, the first year, every three months and then after that two to five years every six months, and then after that if everything stays okay then once a year. Patient: Because I take this serious. Doctor: Okay I can see that. Patient: I take this very, very, very serious. Doctor: The whole thing and I’m glad.

Patient: Hum. Hum. Doctor: And we’ll compare it to all the ones before. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: This is not a huge jump. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Nothing that I’m going to freak out about. But we want to be prepared in case it’s starting to wake up. Patient: Hum. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: In case. Now, it wasn’t like you went all the way down zero and stayed there. So you were always around a one to two. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You know? You’re in the fours a couple of times now, so. Patient: Um hum. Could it be because I’ll be in the sun a lot? Doctor: No.

Family Member 1: In the last two weeks. But we knew it was all for your spine, been that for two years. Doctor: Great. Sorry about that. I just needed to check. Huh, huh, so we also, you know, checked your molecular stuff and there wasn’t anything that jumped out, huh, that says that we have something that we could add a treatment to. You crying? What’s that about? Patient: Dying. Dying. Doctor: Do you feel like you’re dying or just that’s-? Patient: Well you know it’s going to happen. Doctor: Okay. Huh, you have questions, or just-? Patient: I just want to be around a little bit longer, that’s all. Doctor: Well, our hope is that as well. Huh, my sense is, you know, these next drugs we, huh, huh, can get you a little bit more mileage, and you still haven’t had chemotherapy, which could get you some mileage. Huh, there’s an IV radiation drug that can get you a mileage. Most of it’s kicking the can down the street. Huh, we’ve got clinical trials at different points of new drugs, different drugs, combinations of drugs, huh, that we could think about. Huh, yes, so there’s a lot of things out there. It’s a matter of how much you want to go through, the rest of your body, your heart, the other things can get through because the next two drugs, we pick one of them. Huh, one of them is abiraterone, which is probably the cheaper of the two. It’s just gone generic. That doesn’t mean it’s cheap. Huh, but it’s about eleven, twelve thousand dollars a month. Huh, we check with your insurance carrier to see how much they cover. Huh, are you, huh, Medicare, Medicaid, huh, regular insurance, or-? Patient: Right now. Family Member: The next couple of days he’s regular insurance, but he’s going to get Medicare the first of March. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: And that will help out. Patient: March first I start Medicare plus a supplement.

Family Member: He’s vaping. Doctor: Okay that’s probably not going to do anything. Right? Patient: Um it gave me a little bit and maybe it’s just a mental thing. Doctor: Mm hmm. Patient: Give a little bit of comfort. Doctor: Um hum. Well and you could do that, but I think there are other true medicines that you could try to kind of knock down the pain. Patient: Why did you say it wouldn’t be – you just don’t think they work? Doctor: Well just in all the other patients that have sort of done that, they need to do it with something else. It’s just not strong enough. Patient: Okay, yeah, okay. I can’t say it goes away you know Doctor: Mm hmm. Patient: maybe it calms me down Doctor: Yeah.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::strongly agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.strongly agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::strongly agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: Good. Family Member: We like him very much. (Chuckles) Doctor: Okay, anything else? Patient: That’s it. Family Member: That’s it. Doctor: Let me see what we have in here in terms of just follow-up. So he’s already set up for his shot. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So January thirtieth. Family Member: Okay, right. Doctor: So everything else that we’re going to add up now will be related to the study. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Right, okay. Doctor: So, a lot of people are different in their activity level. You know, some folks are just go, go, go, and some are like Patient: RIght. Doctor: oh, no, I like to chill and be on my computer and watch my TV and get on the phone, you know, so everyone’s activity level. Patient: I like more activity. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: But it’s harder for me Doctor: Yeah. Patient: because it brings me down because the next day I can’t do nothing, you know. Doctor: Exactly. Patient: And I don’t like that. Doctor: Yeah. This is common.

Patient: I think, I think you answered all my questions pretty good. Huh, the only thing, the chemo. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: When would that start? Doctor: Huh, so, it, that would start if you are doing the clinical trial, then once you sign the paper, you could start a couple of days after that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so it’s not going to delay getting that started. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, I still would want at least one or two weeks off of the abiraterone before I would get started. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So if you, you know, end up telling me, you know, this doesn’t make sense for me. Huh, we might make the decision when you’re back in a month, huh, and then we can go from there. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you need a refill on your morphine? Or are you good? Patient: No. I’m good with the morphine.

Family Member: So if his bone scan shows progression, are you gonna be in touch with him then? Doctor: I am. Family Member: Then he will start that? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. And either way I think I will give him a head’s up especially – do you know when – do you have an appointment to see him? Patient: No, no, not right now we don’t. Doctor: So if you want to come off then you should probably make an appointment with him. Okay because ah - regardless if the PSA is going up or if the scan is you know not even changing. If you want to come off study Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: then yeah it might be a good idea to make that so we sort of connect with him. Okay? Patient: Yep. Doctor: Does that sound good? Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Yes. So I just want to be patient. Doctor: Okay, and it may, and it very well may, because it’s just, uh, let’s see, it was done, you had the operation on-. Patient: Uh, on the fourteenth of September. Doctor: September? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So you’re not quite a year? Patient: Okay. Doctor: So alright well let’s, let’s continue with the same course. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And see what happens, alright? Patient: Um hum. I’ve been working and so, so you know, I’ve been keeping busy without that. Doctor: Okay. Okay. Alright. Very good.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So you know all of this is, one, you have to be okeydokey with the plan. Two, there’s no emergency, but I always like to stay ahead of your cancer. Family Member: Ahead of the game. Yeah. Doctor: So that’s why we’re having this discussion. Hum, and, three, you know, you don’t like this, then we move onto pills. You know? And there I have different trials, different options, and things like that. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It’s just that I always like to try to get this one in. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Because we have the opportunity. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So here we are. (pause3sec) Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Do you want the paperwork to read?

Patient: Well, they’re giving me a combination. Healthcare Professional: Um hum. Doctor: Anything is possible. (Laughter) Patient: It got better. Family Member: It got better. Doctor: Nice to see you. Nice to see you. Family Member: Hi. Nice to see you. Doctor: So, you know, you done good. Family Member: It got better. Doctor: How about that? Family Member: Good news. No new treatments. Doctor: Yeah. I think you get a break for six weeks until I torture you with that, I mean help you, again.

Patient: Oh, I’m I’m just got the pain medicine going on. Just tired ‘cause I’ve been sitting, I’ve went down there and then I’m sitting out there ‘cause it was you know busy so I’ve been sitting out there for… Doctor: Wow because your appointment was way before I’ve seen so many people so I thought you weren’t here. Patient: No I was over here at the lab. It was so packed over there. Doctor: Oh my gosh you’re kidding me. Patient: Yes. Doctor: How is the pain? (patient makes a noise) Patient: Yeah I took some ah I took my pain medicine… Doctor: Pain medicine. Patient: …before I got here. Doctor: Any better though since we started the chemo? Did you notice any difference in your appetite in your – how you’re feeling? I still feel kind of you know I just had heat flashes and all of that, but the pills that you gave me. Patient: They make me crazy. I was just… Doctor: I think, I think also I started you on the Prednisone remember for your along with the Chemo. Patient: Right.

Patient: We have my father-in-law, Dr. ____ on the phone. Doctor: Okay, hi R____. Family Member: Hi, good morning. Doctor: Yeah, so uh, uh, I think you met them all before. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: and so welcome back, unfortunately. (chuckles) Patient: Right, right. Doctor: So you uh, we went through uh the you know clinical trial and you went to surgery, and uh when they did the surgery uh you had some lymph nodes uh that popped up, and we uh wanted to get a better sense of using the special PSMA scan, uh what was going on, where there was cancer left. And so we had to do the scan, and uh the good news is we found prostate cancer. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh, and uh the bad news is we found prostate cancer, but we sort of knew it was there. Patient: Right. Doctor: And and what we saw on the scan basically is in your pelvis here, from here down to where the prostate was there’s still a lot of lymph nodes with prostate cancer in them. The good news is we didn’t see any higher; so it sort of ends at the pelvis, and we didn’t see any in the bones.

Patient: That’s why I’m always like at that time when I was low or no pain and that’s why he was thinking that’s what we… Doctor: Yeah, Yes, that would have been. Yeah. Patient: Okay. I understand that now. Doctor: So, like back then would have been or if we get you stable and kind of quiet and good we could always redo it, Patient: We can still. Okay. Okay. Doctor: Right. So, it’s not off the table forever. It’s just at this moment it’s not. Patient: At this moment, I understand that, okay. Doctor: Good. Family Member: I have one more question. Doctor: Yeah, go ahead. Family Member: Because he, when we last saw Dr. V____ in Vegas in July he was telling us there’s some research but it will be seven or eight months out. So that was July so it wouldn’t be until like next month about combining radium with the docetaxel. Doctor: Yeah, yeah, so that’s already actually in trial. It is… Family Member: He thought it was better for the body.
